data.title: What sorts of artifacts can I find in the Diefenbunker’s collections and archives?
data.description:
The Diefenbunker aims to increase, throughout Canada and the world, interest in and a critical understanding of the Cold War, by preserving the Diefenbunker as a national historic site, and operating a Cold War museum. The museum holds over 11,000 3-D and 2-D artifacts relevant to Canada’s Cold War history, spanning between 1945 and 1991.

Items in our collections are categorized into three levels:
Level 1: objects originally within the site during its operational life (1962 to 1994)
Level 2: objects adjacent to the site but not used within our site (e.g., from other Canadian Cold War bunkers)
Level 3: objects related to Canadian and international Cold War history and culture (1945 to 1991) but not directly related to the history of our site

Learn more about the Diefenbunker’s collections at diefenbunker.ca/collections.

data.title: How do I search for artifacts?
data.description:
Begin by typing a keyword search into the search bar. You can then refine your search by using the sort and filter options within the search page.

You can also print records or bookmark items to reference again. Please note that your bookmarks will be cleared once you close the webpage in your web browser.

data.title: I can’t find what I’m looking for — what do I do?
data.description: Please try another search term. If you still can’t find what you are looking for, please contact the Diefenbunker’s Curatorial team by email at s.campbell@diefenbunker.ca or by phone at 613-839-0007 x253.

data.title: I have questions about copyright or accessing the artifacts — who can I contact?
data.description: For specific project requests, please contact the Diefenbunker’s Curatorial team by email at s.campbell@diefenbunker.ca or by phone at 613-839-0007 x253.

data.title: How can I donate to the collections?
data.description: If you wish to inquire about donating items to our collections, please contact the Diefenbunker’s Curatorial team by email at s.campbell@diefenbunker.ca or by phone at 613-839-0007 x253.

data.title: Where can I learn more about the Diefenbunker?
data.description:
The Diefenbunker, a once-top secret, four-storey underground bunker, was originally designed as the centre for Canada’s defence against nuclear attack during the Cold War. It is now a one-of-a-kind museum and national historic site, offering unique and immersive experiences for visitors year-round.

Learn more about our guided tours, exhibitions, programs, events, and other offerings at diefenbunker.ca.
